temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated 加粗几个字母之后，英语阅读速度原地起飞，真的这么神奇吗？ in the user temberature at 2022-06-02T07:14:02
item.description:
in reference to:

这也解释了仿生阅读为什么妨碍了习惯扫读的读者。对于这些人来说，可能整体高亮关键词、或者高亮句首、段首会更有用。

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated 加粗几个字母之后，英语阅读速度原地起飞，真的这么神奇吗？ in the user temberature at 2022-06-02T07:15:27
item.description:
in reference to:

从这个角度来讲，仿生阅读也未必适用于所有文章。沈阳师范大学曾做过一项文本标注对中文阅读眼动的研究。研究显示，虽然添加高亮会指引和帮助参与者们更好地记忆重点内容、忽略干扰内容，但如果含有错误标识或标识过多，那与无标识的阅读效率几乎是一样的。同时，如果阅读的文本是比较简单的内容，那标示也未必可以提高正确率。

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.description:

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated 中医这件事 in the user temberature at 2022-06-25T14:17:45
item.description:
in reference to:

所以后来索性把医生的眼睛也蒙起来——不告诉医疗人员哪组是安慰剂组哪组是实验组，所有的结果由第三方机构去统计和评判，这就是双盲对照实验。这种测试最大限度地排除了病人的安慰剂效应和医生的主观偏好，成为了判断药物客观疗效最有力的证据，现代医学的“金标准”。

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated MasterHowToLearn - Why 99% People Never Learned How To Learn And How to Become That 1% (I) in the user temberature at 2022-08-08T11:22:29
item.description:
in reference to:

some of the reasons have nothing to do with choosing the “best learning tool,” but with regards to how my workflow and my life have changed.

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated MasterHowToLearn - Why 99% People Never Learned How To Learn And How to Become That 1% (I) in the user temberature at 2022-08-08T11:34:26
item.description:
in reference to:

Linking makes the thinking process tangible: links are the proofs that you’ve connected the material with your prior knowledge. Having a lot of unlinked notes is also proof that different pieces of information exist in isolation.

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated MasterHowToLearn - Why 99% People Never Learned How To Learn And How to Become That 1% (I) in the user temberature at 2022-08-08T11:44:26
item.description:
in reference to:

From now on, my focus on “how to learn” would be shifted from “when should I review this” to “what should I do when I indeed review this?” It’ll be about thinking frameworks and mental models; it’s about “what and how to think” instead of “when to think.”

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.description:

Give it time and it will become second nature.

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated r/vim - Has anyone ever felt like the cognitive load of using motions balances out any benefits? in the user temberature at 2022-08-13T02:34:35
item.description:
in reference to:

You are still using your head. At some point most of the things that are vim related won't be processed by your brain but by your muscle memory.

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.description:
in reference to:

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated r/vim - Has anyone ever felt like the cognitive load of using motions balances out any benefits? in the user temberature at 2022-08-13T02:35:35
item.description:
in reference to:

Over time you will figure out your preferred motions and work flow. You will develop muscle memory for most of it and it will be intuitive (直观) and instinctive (本能) .

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated r/vim - Has anyone ever felt like the cognitive load of using motions balances out any benefits? in the user temberature at 2022-08-13T02:44:45
item.description:
in reference to:

Learning to use vim really is like learning a language. You're still "translating" in your head instead of just "speaking" naturally. Just keep practicing and it will become second nature with time.

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated Automating Read It Later Articles to DEVONthink - GeekDad in the user temberature at 2022-08-27T04:50:54
item.description:
in reference to:

So when you see something you want to dive into later when you have a bit more time… you have to put it somewhere. That is where a “read-it-later” service like Pocket or Instapaper comes in. Basic features with these services are free, but if you want more advanced features like “search” you have to pay. In the case of Pocket, it will cost you $4.99 a month or $44.99 a year to keep a permanent library of saved articles and be able to search the content of those articles.

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated At What Age Does Our Ability to Learn a New Language Like a Native Speaker Disappear? in the user temberature at 2022-09-02T03:03:33
item.description:
in reference to:

In what could be the most surprising conclusion, the researchers say that even among native speakers it takes 30 years to fully master a language. The study showed a slight improvement—roughly one percentage point—in people who have been speaking English for 30 versus 20 years. The finding is consistent for both native and non-native speakers.

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated How long does it take to master a language like a native speaker? in the user temberature at 2022-09-02T03:10:21
item.description:
in reference to:

I find that memorizing a number of ‘filler’ words or sentences can greatly increase your ability to come off as native, as well as knowing some expressions and sayings. Instead of expressing agreement with a simple ‘yes’ you could try responding with “you know what? I Agree!” or “I think I see what you mean”. It’s agreement either way but it sounds a lot more ‘native’.

item.description:
in reference to:

We want to create notes that are relevant to contexts important to us, not just related to the book we read.

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated How To Take Smart Notes –– Sonke Ahrens in the user temberature at 2022-11-10T06:56:29
item.description:
in reference to:

"Permanent notes are to be written in a way that can still be understood even when you have forgotten the context they are taken from. "

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated How To Take Smart Notes –– Sonke Ahrens in the user temberature at 2022-11-10T06:57:04
item.description:
in reference to:

We want to file information in the context we want to rediscover it in, not the context that we found it in.

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated How To Take Smart Notes –– Sonke Ahrens in the user temberature at 2022-11-10T07:00:56
item.description:
in reference to:

Useful learning is to connect a piece of information to as many meaningful contexts as possible, which is what we do when we connect our notes in the slip-box with other notes.

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated How to Take Smart Notes by Sonke Ahrens in the user temberature at 2022-11-10T07:02:47
item.description:
in reference to:

What differentiates the Smart Notes method from other note-taking methods is it recognizes that a note is only as useful as the context it is embedded in – its network of associations, relationships, and connections to other ideas.

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated How to Take Smart Notes by Sonke Ahrens in the user temberature at 2022-11-10T07:04:00
item.description:
in reference to:

In the new system, the question is: In which context will I want to stumble upon it again?”

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated How to Take Smart Notes by Sonke Ahrens in the user temberature at 2022-11-10T07:05:01
item.description:
in reference to:

Ideally, you want to do this once a day before you forget the context of the notes you’ve already taken.

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated How to Take Smart Notes by Sonke Ahrens in the user temberature at 2022-11-10T07:07:43
item.description:
in reference to:

Don’t simply copy your notes into a rough draft, but translate them into something coherent and embed them into the context of your argument. As you detect any holes in your argument, fill them in, or change your argument.

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated Git - Git Configuration in the user temberature at 2022-11-15T04:43:42
item.description:
in reference to:

Git can handle this by auto-converting CRLF line endings into LF when you add a file to the index, and vice versa when it checks out code onto your filesystem. You can turn on this functionality with the core.autocrlf setting. If you’re on a Windows machine, set it to true — this converts LF endings into CRLF when you check out code: $ git config --global core.autocrlf true

temberature@hypothes.is said:

item.title: temberature@hypothes.is annotated Git - git-config Documentation in the user temberature at 2022-11-15T05:16:38
item.description:
in reference to:

core.autocrlf Setting this variable to "true" is the same as setting the text attribute to "auto" on all files and core.eol to "crlf". Set to true if you want to have CRLF line endings in your working directory and the repository has LF line endings. This variable can be set to input, in which case no output conversion is performed.

temberature@hypothes.is said:
